subject: Re: [junit] Is a regression testing framework available?

messageBody:
Daniel,

On Wednesday, March 19, 2003, at 08:56 AM, Vladimir R. Bossicard wrote:

>> I would like to be able to find out which tests that have stopped
>> working between two of our nightly builds (which run a set of JUnit
>> tests). Since we currently have more than 500 test cases it is
>> difficult to do this manually. It would of course be easy if the
>> normal success rate was 100%, but a number of test cases fail since
>> the implementation is not yet completed.
>
> Funny I discussed that with Bill Venners a few days ago.
>
Yes, Vladimir and I did talk about this last week over turkey burgers.
We spent most of the lunch comparing Vladimir's JUnit Add-Ons with
SuiteRunner. It turns out we were both trying to address many of the
same issues when we built our respective JUnit extensions.

> Your problem is that not all of your tests pass. So my question is:
> how can a
> developer be sure that he didn't introduce a bug with some new code?
> X tests
> were failing before the modification and now Y tests are failing. If
> Y>X you
> don't know which one is/are now failing.
>
> IMO opinion (and in your case) you have two kinds of failing tests:
> - the one that shouldn't
> - the one that will, and it's ok (testing not implemented features, not
> implemented tests)
>
> JUnit doesn't directly give you the possibility to separate the "good"
> from the
> "bad" failing tests. You have to come up with your own solution.
>
> What I would do:
> - rename the tests that should fail testXYZ_failing
> - rewrite some JUnit components (it depends what kind of runner you're
> using
> (ant, swing, textui) to filter these tests
> - or write an XSLT file to process the XML and remove the '_failing'
> methods
> from the report
>
I had never imagined this kind of problem before talking to Vladimir,
but this morning I realized that it sounds like a good candidate for a
custom reporter. If you use SuiteRunner as your JUnit runner, you can
create a custom reporter that I think will solve your problem. This
reporter should:

1. Record persistently (in a database or file, for example) the tests
that fail.
2. Open up the persistent record of failed tests from the previous run,
compare that with the current set of failed tests, and indicate the
differences to the user.

A couple weeks ago I published an article about how to create a custom
reporter that should get you started:

http://www.artima.com/suiterunner/xmlreporter.html

If you run into trouble, please post to the SuiteRunner forum and we'll
try and help:

http://www.artima.com/forums/forum.jsp?forum=61

Bill
